title: Thursday, 14th March 2019
bodyHTML:
11:07 am

11:16 am

Though net debt was still a fairly dangerous 3.7x at the end of the year for a business that's effectively a retail park play.

red there will be at least one english pairing, odds otherwise tiny
red barca will get porto of course, or spurs
lonrho Capita please
OnYourRight Morning all
BE11:16am

The first question -- and there are several -- is whether 2018 was a typical year in cinema.

BE11:17am

I'll let JPM do the numbers .....

11:17 am
BE11:17am

US admissions grew 4.9% on a pro-forma basis to 206.5m (vs. JPMe 202.3m), and vs. a market increase of 5.3%. Box office revenue grew by 7.2%, Retail by 8.2% and Other Income by 18.3%. Total US revenue grew by 8.6% on a pro-forma basis to $3,525.3m (vs. JPMe $3,520m). The top three films for the year were ‘Black Panther’, ‘Avengers: Infinity War’, and ‘Incredibles 2’. ATP increased by 2.2% to $10.32 and retail SPP by 3.1%. The US added alcoholic beverage availability at 35 sites and an expanded food offering in 14 sites during the year. US EBITDA was up 13.2% to $817.4m with margins up 90 bps to 23.2%.
 UK&I: In a year of distractions for the UK consumer, both adverse (i.e. sunny) weather and English sporting success, UK&I admissions declined 2.6% to 51.6m (vs. JPMe 52.2m). Box office take declined by 1.5% on a constant currency basis, Retail declined by 0.2% and Other Income grew by 7%. Total UK&I revenue declined by 0.4% to $697.7m (vs. JPMe $695m). The top three films for the year were ‘Avengers: Infinity War’, ‘Mamma Mia: Here We Go Again’, and ‘Incredibles 2’. ATP increased by 1.2% on a constant currency basis to $8.79. At year-end the group had 32 Starbucks sites (+3 vs 2017), and two VIP auditoriums. Retail SPP rose 2.5% c/c to $3.25. UK&I EBITDA was down 3.7% to $125.9m with margins down 130 bps to 18.0%, 60 bps above forecast.

BE11:17am

Okay, so superhero movies and a Mama Mia sequel.

nightingale20201 morning all
Tom Dalgleish The average American went to the movies 3 or more times a week in the 1950's
Mr Ticker Kin & Carta please BE....
BE11:19am

Though it was also a year when a Star Wars movie flopped. One can ponder how much is left in the Marvel franchise, and how much sequels aimed at older audiences do for your popcorn sales ....

11:19 am
BE11:19am

.... and you can ponder how much the cinema clubs and the bundled stuff with insurers and restaurant groups and etc is undermining overall pricing power .....

BE11:20am

Or you can ignore all that, likce Citi does.

BE11:20am

 Implications — While the film slate has been soft YTD, we expect the shares to be supported by the positive integration of Regal cinemas, stronger box office releases in 2Q19e and upgrade to synergies. We forecast Cineworld to have FY19e +3.7% pro-forma sales growth and $1,126 million EBITDA, based on the previous synergy guidance.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And Ivor Jones at Peel Hunt, who's a tad more cautious.

BE11:21am

Every movie plot has a tricky bit in the middle so that everything
can get sorted out in the end. 2019 is Cineworld’s tricky bit
when it carries on with Regal refurbishment and, with a backend
weighted release schedule, can’t decisively prove the
payback on investment. Upgrading synergies is a hopeful sign.

Finlay Thursday is usually the juiciest day for news...mid-March lull?
BE11:22am

 Strong performance from the US, which accounted for 71% of Group pro
forma revenue in FY18. US revenue was up 8.6%. Management actions
included introducing seat reservations (increasing dwell time and retail sales), increased online bookings (and fees) and some refurb projects. We expect c10 strategic refurbishment projects in 2019 with helpful landlord contributions.
• US Box Office revenue (61% of the total) increased by 7.2% pro forma
(admissions up 4.9%, ticket prices up 2.2%). US industry box office
revenue was up 6.9% on a strong release schedule.
• US Retail revenue (29% of the total) was up 8.2% pro forma, with spend
per head up 3.1%.
 UK and Ireland revenue fell by 0.4% (cc), affected by the heatwave and the World Cup. Admissions were down 2.6% and prices were up 1.2%. Retail
revenue was down 0.2% (cc) and suffered from the footfall decline; spend per head was up 2.5% (cc).
 Current trading in January/February was probably weak, up against a
strong comp. Major films will help the 2Q, including “Captain Marvel”,
“Dumbo” and “Avengers: Endgame” and the schedule is strong at year end.
We believe Cineworld will become increasingly attractive to investors as the strong cash flow rapidly pays down the debt (to 2.5x Net Debt/EBITDA at end-FY20 from 3.7x pro forma at the end of FY18E). With the shares trading on c12x FY19E P/E we reiterate our Add rating and 320p target price.

St Andrean Everyone at the Races?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Marconi please. :)
nightingale20201 very blue sky at Citi!!!
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Captain Marvel, Dumbo and Avengers: Endgame. Sounds to me like a golden age of Hollywood.

madrugada It's interesting to compare the price of cinema tickets cross Europe. Zurich is the most expensive 25 francs. Central London isn't far behind.
BE11:24am

We've mentioned before it's rather odd that out-of-town mall operators have been destroyed, as have captive-customer restaurant groups like .... um .... Restaurant Group, but Cineworld remains relatively untouched despite working on very similar consumer dynamics.

BE11:24am

.... with the added angle of Netflix, as well as a management over whom there remains some caution.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Anyway. that's that.

Numbers are underwhelming, guidance is cautious:

BE11:29am

 Revenue down 5% (flat LfL) to £87.2m from £91.7m in 18
 PBT down 4% to £8.0m from £8.4m in 18
 Adjusted EPS down 9% to 4.21p from 4.65p in 18
 Net debt up to £33.3m from £26.0m in August 18

Outlook comment: “Whilst we still have much to do to generate higher returns from our businesses, we believe we are on track to meet the Board’s expectations for Adjusted profit before tax for the current year.”
Headline numbers: Note this half has 26 weeks vs 27 in the prior period

BE11:29am

That's via Peel Hunt, who step back forecasts by a tad.

Blank canvas Thanks for Cineworld. If you are scraping around for something, how about Savills (SVS). No holdings in either.
11:29 am
BE11:30am

Trading detail: Reported revenue declined as the number of billable days
reduced from 135 to 129 as the company reported on a 26 – not 27 – week
period. The company is now reporting on a calendar month basis. The
Innovations division grew 18% and now represents 46% of the group, driven by good client wins and the expansion of the scope of existing client work. Strategy declined 8% as the focus on integrating more effectively the three units (Incite Hive and Pragma) to form a relevant DX strategic service was executed.
Communications revenue, down 14%, continued to see some GDPR pressure as well as the deliberate move away from lower-margin non-DX work. Group margin at 10.5% vs 10.7% last year.
Financing: Net debt rose to £33m. Operating cash flow was limited by a £3.2m working capital outflow (mainly reduced payables). Offsetting this, the receipt of £7.2m of proceeds from the sale of the Redditch warehouse partially helped fund
the £13.0m deferred consideration payment (Solstice £3.3m, Tab £9.7m).
Implication for forecasts: The continued focus on DX work will see H2
Comm’s and Strategy growth still muted. Excellent Innovations growth of near 40% in H2 is outstanding, but overall we reduce our revenue target by c £4m or 2%. Growth in higher-margin work at the expense of lower-margin commodity work ensures no change in profit expectations.

BE11:30am

Hope that helps.

BE11:46am

TTWO was up near 7% yesterday off trading desk stories that a West Coast brokerage firm had suggested that a deal is imminent - even with no credible sources to suggest that Sony's board was actually "in advanced board level discussions to acquire TTWO in a mostly cash deal". The notion that Sony would use exclusivity on Red Dead Redemption and a Grand Theft Auto 6 launch to
bolster a PS5 launch seems ambitious, as GTA and Red Dead Redemption are all-time best selling entertainment franchises with economics that depend on cross-platform availability. BRG's upside TTWO assessment is $159 (+66%), with downside to $82 (-15%).

red here in poland a game company has gone from zero to a billion mktcap and main index, but really its only as good as its next game. seems a lot of risk to me
11:46 am
BE11:46am

We do look for continued consolidation in the video game publishing
space, exemplified by Microsoft's (MSFT-NR) E3 2018 announcements of
multiple smaller studio purchases. Sony's focus has largely been on first party exclusives like God of War and Uncharted 4. Our lead candidate for a 2019 'whale' acquisition by Microsoft, Sony or a U.S. publisher might even be now AT&T (T-NR) owned Warner Interactive Entertainment, with its franchises
around DC Comics, Harry Potter, Lego and Mortal Kombat.
A Sony acquisition of TTWO might make the most sense if there was a
simultaneous major pivot where it actually sold its Sony Pictures and media networks. This is inconsistent with highly credible overnight media reports that Sony will imminently buy a 20-25% position in India's Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd. (ZEEL-NR).

Capita? If we must.

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 124.85, up 5.1 (+4.26%), High: 127.60, Low: 114.60, Volume: 6.35m
Manxish Thanks, BE/Rabble
11:57 am
BE11:58am

Resutlts beat, outlook bleak.

BE11:58am

UBS can summarise.

BE11:58am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: FY'18 PBTA of £282m came in above company guidance range £250-275m,
although Net Debt was slightly higher than UBSe. As expected, there is still no dividend.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Organic growth of -5% in FY'18 implies a deceleration to -6% in H2. In-year cost
savings of £70m were as expected, with EBITA margins 8.7% (-220bps y/y). Free cash
flow -£260m was below UBSe, but this includes clearing the entire £110m receivables
financing programme and so was better than expected on an underlying basis.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: 2020 targets remain double-digit margins and greater than £200m of FCF (pre-exceptionals).
2019 is seen as a second transition year, with adj. PBT guidance £265-295m i.e.
between -7% and +5% y/y despite accelerating savings plans to achieve the full £175m
a year early. It sees Net Debt/EBITDA to be in the 'top half' of target range 1.5-2.0x.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: FY'19e guidance may look weak, but underlying cashflow was better than expected.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

And Goldman.

Patience @rvj - Baillie Gifford have been good for me over the years. Japan Smaller companies, Pacific B accumulator in particular.
BE11:59am

Capita announced FY18 results with adjusted pre-tax profit of £282mn, slightly ahead of our and consensus expectations of £274mn/£266mn. Full year revenues came in c.1-2% below our and consensus expectations as the company is shifting its mix towards higher margin divisions [such as Software or IT & Network divisions], while its Government Services division (with margins below the sector average) saw double digit revenue contraction. Capita’s order book shrank to c.£7.1 [from £7.7bn in 1H18], however the company remains committed to returning to organic growth and double digit EBIT margins in 2020 as it increases its commercial focus particularly on the faster growing and higher margins divisions. Capita is guiding for an adjusted pre-tax profit for 2019 of £265-295mn, which, at the mid-point, is slightly below the company-compiled consensus of £292mn for 2019. The company year end 2018 net debt/adj EBITDA came in at 1.2x, however Capita is guiding for leverage to be in the upper part of its 1-2x stated range [before the adoption of IFRS16].

BE11:59am

The company stated that it expects to accelerate its cost savings, realizing £175mn already by 2019 (rather than 2020). However, we note that, despite this, the company’s 2019 guidance is broadly in line with current consensus (in fact the midpoint of £280mn of adjusted pre-tax profit is some 4% below the company compiled consensus), suggesting that the company is also incurring higher costs than previously anticipated as it tries to re-energize its commercial effort and return to growth.

12:00 pm
undefined

As for Just Group .....

Just Group PLC (JUST:LSE): Last: 85.80, down 11.7 (-12.00%), High: 88.00, Low: 79.00, Volume: 12.44m
12:01 pm

It's pulled the trigger on the fundraising everyone knew it needed.

cheeckychappy @BE - You should be a stand up comedian. You will make a lot more money.
BE12:02pm

The main surprise is structure, which seems to please no one.

OnYourRight Cheers BE/ROTR
BE12:03pm

They've included a 9,99% cashbox placing, so the people expecting a rights issue are disappointed that there's more debt and the people who wanted solely debt are disappointed that there's dilution.

hornblower @kemce - why do you say that re MTRO
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

In camp #1 we have Panmure Gordon.

BE12:04pm

Just Group has delivered its 2018 results, but the focus of the day will be on its capital actions which in our view will secure its solvency position at least in the medium. Following the agreement January shareholder approval, Just has announced a fully underwritten £300m Restricted Tier 1 (RT1) Bond issue together with a 9.99% placing to raise c£80m via an ABB which, combined is expected to increase its SII Solvency ratio from 136% at 2018 year end to a much more comfortable c160%. We think that the market was anticipating the RT1 issue but not the placing although in our view, despite the likely impact on EPS, the move addresses the capital uncertainty that has overhung the company since CP13/18 was issued last year. In the short term we anticipate that the shares will be under pressure given the surprise placing.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE12:05pm

|n Camp #2 we have JP Morgan.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Alongside FY18 results, Just Group has also made a few announcements regarding capital and dividends. Key
highlights are that 1) Just Group is planning to raise c. £380m capital (c. £80m equity and £300m T1 debt) and
this compares with our expectation of £400m equity raise, 2) it is not paying dividends in 2018 (inline with
JPMe, but below 2.3p consensus), although it plans to resume dividend payment from 2019 onwards of around
1.24p a share (JPMe 0p and BBG consensus 3.9p/4.0p in 2019e/2020e), 3) it expects its Solvency II capital
generation to break even in 2022, i.e. three years from now, and 4) operating earnings came in at £210m vs.
consensus £213m which included -£33m assumption changes which could be seen as a one-off.
 Capital fix: Just Group has announced a £380m capital raise this morning of which it plans to raise c. £80m
equity and £300m T1 debt. The headline number is inline with our expectation of £400m capital raise needed;
however, we expected it to be equity raise whereas Just Group is raising more debt. This would support
headline Solvency II as it would move from 136% to 160% and would reduce the dilution we expected; we
note that this would increase debt leverage to c. 33% on a headline basis and to c. 36% on a tangible equity
basis which we believe is high compared to sector average.
 Dividend: Management have decided not to pay a dividend for 2018 which is inline with our expectation but
below consensus 2.3p. However, management do plan to pay 1.24p a share from 2019 onwards (vs. JPMe 0p
and BBG consensus 3.9p). Management mentioned that they expect Solvency II capital generation to break
even by 2022 and thus we believe that paying a dividend after achieving breakeven on S2 capital generation
would have been our preference.
 Operating earnings for the year came in at £210m vs. consensus £213m. Although it’s a headline miss by
1%, we note that there is an assumption change negative impact of £33m, excluding which earnings were
better than expected. This was mainly driven by higher than expected new business margin of 11% (consensus
9.4%).
 Overall we believe that it’s a step in the right direction on capital; however, a bit more equity and a bit
less debt would have been our preferred route.

LegalEagle Thanks @BE and @ROTR.
BE12:05pm

And in neither camp we have RBC

BE12:05pm

Just Group is the only insurer not to release mortality reserves in 2018
results. Just Group incurred a £34m loss from operating assumption
changes. Consensus had nil for this item, while we expected a mortality
gain of £48m. This item includes a gain from a mortality reserve release
on the annuity book, more than offset by a loss from changes in
the life expectancy assumptions on the equity release mortgage book.
Economically, lower life expectancy is good for equity release mortgage
books as insurers will get their capital back sooner, reducing the risk of
the No Negative Equity Guarantee biting. The exact contribution between
the offsetting assumption changes has not been disclosed, but overall
we believe it is likely that the assumptions result is similar to the 2017
mortality result that we analysed.
No dividend in 2018 given the capital actions. We had expected this to be
withheld, given the previous messaging from the company which stated
"... the Board is continuing to consider the optimal capital mix". Just Group
expects to reinstate the dividend in 2019E at a rebased level, which the
company have stated will be around one third of the 2017 level.
We still rate Just Group as a Top Pick. Prior to the announcement this
morning, we have Just Group on a P/E (2019E) of 3x vs a sector average
of 9x. The equity placing will dilute the earnings, but Just Group is in the
sweet spot of significant bulk
